goals.question: What is the distribution of population by age group?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of population by age group
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the age distribution of the population and identify any age groups that may require special attention or resources.

goals.question: What is the trend of population growth over the years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of population growth over the years
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the trend of population growth over the years and identify any significant changes or patterns.

goals.question: What is the distribution of population by gender?
goals.visualization: Pie chart of population by gender
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the gender distribution of the population and identify any gender-based disparities or issues.

goals.question: What is the distribution of population by region?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the geographic distribution of the population and identify any regional disparities or issues.

goals.question: What is the distribution of population by education level?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of population by education level
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the education level distribution of the population and identify any education-based disparities or issues.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    age_groups = data.groupby('age_group').sum()
    age_groups.plot(kind='bar', y='population')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of population by age group?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['year'], format='%Y', errors='coerce')
    data = data.sort_values(by='year')
    plt.plot(data['year'], data['population'], color='blue')
    plt.title('What is the trend of population growth over the years?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Population')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    gender_counts = data['gender'].value_counts()
    labels = gender_counts.index.tolist()
    sizes = gender_counts.values.tolist()
    fig1, ax1 = plt.subplots()
    ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', startangle=90)
    ax1.axis('equal')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of population by gender?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.groupby('region').sum()
    data = data.reset_index()
    plt.bar(data['region'], data['population'])
    plt.title('What is the distribution of population by region?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Region')
    plt.ylabel('Population')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.groupby(['education_level'])['population'].sum().reset_index()
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    ax.bar(data['education_level'], data['population'], color='blue')
    ax.set_xlabel('Education Level')
    ax.set_ylabel('Population')
    ax.set_title('What is the distribution of population by education level?')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
